title: Sleep basics
summary: Healthy sleep habits that improve quality and consistency.
advice: Keep a consistent sleep/wake time, even on weekends.
Make your room cool, dark, and quiet; avoid screens for 60 minutes before bed.
Limit caffeine to earlier in the day; try a wind-down routine.
If you can’t sleep, get out of bed and do a calm activity until sleepy again.

title: Coping with stress/anxiety
summary: Quick techniques to lower arousal and manage worry.
advice: Try paced breathing: inhale 4s, hold 4s, exhale 6–8s for 2–3 minutes.
Short, light movement breaks help downshift stress.
Reduce stimulants (caffeine/energy drinks) when anxious.
If persistent or interfering with life, speak with a licensed professional.

title: Headache self-care and red flags
summary: Self-care and when to seek in-person care.
advice: Hydrate, rest in a quiet dark room; consider simple over-the-counter pain relief if appropriate.
Track triggers: sleep, stress, dehydration, skipped meals.
Red flags: sudden worst headache, head injury, fever with stiff neck, vision/speech changes, weakness—seek urgent care.

title: Cold/flu home care
summary: Typical home care and warning signs.
advice: Rest and fluids; consider OTC symptom relief as appropriate.
Seek care if breathing trouble, chest pain, confusion, dehydration, fever > 3–4 days, or rapid worsening.

title: Nutrition basics
summary: Simple plate method for balanced meals.
advice: Build plates with vegetables, lean protein, whole grains, and healthy fats.
Prefer minimally processed foods; make small consistent changes.

title: Movement and exercise
advice: Aim ~150 minutes/week of moderate activity plus two strength sessions.
Start gently and progress gradually; any movement helps.

title: Hydration
advice: Sip water regularly; more in heat, illness, or exercise.
Urine pale-straw color is a simple hydration check.

title: Autism — general information
summary: General information only; diagnosis requires professionals.
advice: Autism involves differences in communication, social interaction, and sensory processing.
Assessments are done by trained clinicians; community resources and support groups can help.
